definitions.definition: a long pointed orange root vegetable
a reward promised to somebody in order to persuade them to do something

examples.text: They are holding out a carrot of $120 million in economic aid.
It's a big carrot he's dangling in front of Marler's nose.
Even with the carrot of a free lunch it is unlikely that many people will turn up.
In a market economy profits are the carrot that encourages firms to take risks.

definitions.definition: if you use the carrot and stick approach, you persuade somebody to try harder by offering them a reward if they do, or a punishment if they do not

examples.text: The emphasis is on the carrot of incentive rather than the stick of taxes.
He decided to use the carrot and stick approach.

wordOrigin: late 15th cent.: from French carotte, from Latin carota, from Greek karōton.
